Award.AwardTitle: Tailoring the Energy Levels of Donor and Acceptor in Organic Photovoltaics for Increased Photovoltage with Ferroelectric Dipole Layer

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is jointly funded by the Energy, Power, and Adaptive Systems Program (EPAS) in the Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems (ECCS) and the Electronic and Photonic Materials Program (EPM) in the Division of Materials Research (DMR).

Research Objectives and Approaches. The objective of this research is to enable large efficiency improvements of Organic Photovoltaic (OPV) devices by focusing on the leading cause of efficiency reduction in OPV devices which occurs in the charge transfer process from donor to acceptor molecules. The approach is to insert an electric dipole layer between the semiconductor donor and acceptor layers to minimize the energy loss with tuned the relative energy levels.

Intellectual merit. This project provides a unique device design rule to increase the open circuit voltage of OPV devices potentially to the thermodynamic limit. This device structure can be applied in any existing polymer system to boost the efficiency without compromising other properties such as the current output or device stability. This is a transformational approach because of its potential to transform OPVs from laboratory subject to vital technology. In addition, the proposed research will provide new fundamental insight into the physics of charge photogeneration, charge collection, and the factors determining photovoltage output of OPV devices.

Broader Impact. The project activities will make significant contributions to scientific knowledge, education, outreach, and will benefit society through technology transfer, training the next generation of scientists and engineers, and informing society about the excitement of organic solar energy production. The project will provide graduate students with innovative opportunities such as industry research experience for graduate students. This project will promote teaching, training, and learning by involving undergraduate involved in the inherently interdisciplinary cooperative research activities and recruiting students from minorities and underrepresented groups.

Institution.Name: University of Nebraska-Lincoln
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative project successfully demonstrated the application of low cost ferroelectric dipole layers in organic photovoltaic to enhance the open circuit voltage without reducing other performance parameters, and successfully achieved the goal of device efficiency above 15%. The enhanced efficiency paved the road for the production of organic and hybrid solar cells. Actually the efficiency was increased to 20% by the end of this project using an advanced organic-inorganic hybrid perovskite light absorber. We demonstrated that adding dipole in between donor and acceptor of heterojunction solar cells is a universal method to tune the performance. This project also started a field on ferroelectric solar cells, where the ferroelectric materials have been introduced into solar cells for enhanced performance and added new functionality. To better control the arrangement of the ferroelectric polymer nanomesas use to enhance charge extraction at the cathode with the bulk heterojunction solar cell and the cathode, we developed a novel low-pressure form of reversal nanoimprint lithography that is suitable for patterning precise nanomesa arrays on top of the soft bulk heterojunction layer.

This project also involved four PhD students, one master students, and four undergraduate students.  Three of the four PhD students received their PhD degree, and the master student received the master degree during this project.  The students received training in all aspects including experiment skills, presentation, reporting, teaching et al. All graduate students from this project successfully lands positions either in academic units of industry. They either continue their academic career by doing postdocs in National Laboratories or Universities, or went to industry/companies. The project yielded totally 24 publications in top notch journals such as Nature Materials, Nature Communications, Energy Environmental Science, Advanced Materials et al, 1 book chapter, and numerous presentations (invited and contribution talks) by the PIs and the PhD students. 

 


Last Modified: 08/03/2016
Modified by: Jinsong Huang
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This collaborative project successfully demonstrated the application of low cost ferroelectric dipole layers in organic photovoltaic to enhance the open circuit voltage without reducing other performance parameters, and successfully achieved the goal of device efficiency above 15%. The enhanced efficiency paved the road for the production of organic and hybrid solar cells. Actually the efficiency was increased to 20% by the end of this project using an advanced organic-inorganic hybrid perovskite light absorber. We demonstrated that adding dipole in between donor and acceptor of heterojunction solar cells is a universal method to tune the performance. This project also started a field on ferroelectric solar cells, where the ferroelectric materials have been introduced into solar cells for enhanced performance and added new functionality. To better control the arrangement of the ferroelectric polymer nanomesas use to enhance charge extraction at the cathode with the bulk heterojunction solar cell and the cathode, we developed a novel low-pressure form of reversal nanoimprint lithography that is suitable for patterning precise nanomesa arrays on top of the soft bulk heterojunction layer. This project also involved four PhD students, one master students, and four undergraduate students. Three of the four PhD students received their PhD degree, and the master student received the master degree during this project. The students received training in all aspects including experiment skills, presentation, reporting, teaching et al. All graduate students from this project successfully lands positions either in academic units of industry. They either continue their academic career by doing postdocs in National Laboratories or Universities, or went to industry/companies. The project yielded totally 24 publications in top notch journals such as Nature Materials, Nature Communications, Energy Environmental Science, Advanced Materials et al, 1 book chapter, and numerous presentations (invited and contribution talks) by the PIs and the PhD students.
